page.title: 12A390 _ HISTORY
page.content: The A390 follows a{trading route used since the Bronze Age, but the modern road dates from{1763}when the {Callington Turnpike Trust}was set up. By{1800}the surface of the road to St Ive was improved using gravel and stone, and{turnpikes}and{tollhouses were set up. {Milestones}erected at this time can still be seen along the road _ at 355689 is one marked{"4 1/3 furlongs {to Callington Market Gate",}while Newbridge milestone shows 7 miles to Liskeard. At the brow of the hill to St Ive (334678) is the{"Take off" stone, where the extra horse taken on at Newbridge (to help coaches up the steep climb) had to be unhitched. The original{turnpike}ran up the Cadson Farm road and to the west of Pencrebar, but toll money was used to cut the present routes in {1874.}
